Input.threadtitle: Lesson 4 question about voice leading in deceptive cadence
Input.posts:
Since the tenor is one of the inner voices, leading tones in the tenor line don't have to resolve to the tonic. The same would apply to alto lines as well. Besides, resolving the tenor to the C would double the third, which is less desirable (not forbidden, but not in general what you want for a chord in root position). Also, having the bass move up while all the other voices move down gives us our desired contrary motion.

Pietro, you are right. If we're in the minor key, going from V to VI with the same voicing would force us to double the third to prevent the augmented 2nd interval in the tenor.

I have a general question about cadences - being pretty new to all this.  My question is when does a progression become a cadence? e.g. I gather we could use a basic progression like I IV V, or I IV V I , and even repeat these without them being cadences. So when we use a cadential progression is is the sense of ending or half ending that makes it a cadence e.g could we have the same progression in the same piece without it being a cadence?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Yes, it is the sense of closure at the end of a phrase that makes it a cadence. You can have progressions of chords that have V-I, or ii-V, iv-V etc. in them, but so long as they are not at the end of a phrase and they don't sound like giving a sense of closure/half-closure, they are not regarded as cadences. Note that to give us this sense of closure/half-closure, you may have to elongate the chord tones belonging to that last chord of the cadence, or include a short break in the music to emphasise that cadence.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Cliff. Sorry for the delayed response. With regard to your first question, the mediant harmony is found less often than the other diatonic harmonies, but it doesn't mean that the chord is not important. I'm sure you already know that you can find the mediant chord used within the progressions such as the Circle of Fifths progression and the Descending 5-6 progressions. You can take a look at them in the Compendium of Progressions under Sequential Progressions. In phrases, we commonly encounter the mediant chord after the tonic chord. For example, in the progression, I-I6-IV-V-I, where we have the mediant as the bass for I6, we can reharmonize this progression as I-iii-IV-V-I, using the mediant chord in rootposition instead. By substituting the I6 with iii, the iii creates a sort of a tonic extension. Also interesting to note that, with alternate reharmonisation you can repurpose the notes in your melody line. What I mean by this is that, take for example,if you are writing in C major with the initial progression I-I6-IV-V-I, and you have the notes C-B-A in your melody from the chords I-I6-IV, the B must be a passing non-chord tone. But with I-iii-IV, you've repurposed the B into a chord tone. The iii usually goes up to the IV as the IV  Also common is where we have the mediant chord going into the submediant chord. Consider the progression, I-vi-ii-V-I. We can insert the iii before vi to give us I-iii-vi-ii-V-i. Notice also how this is a 'shortened version' of the Circle of Fifths progression without the the IV-viio after I.  In the minor key, the mediant chord is usually first prepared by its secondary subdominant. For example, in the key of C minor, the III, Eb major chord, is usually preceded by Bb major chord, the V of III. Hence we have a chord progression such as i-V/III-III-iv-V-i. The V/III can be inverted as V6/III to give us an ascending bass line. Regarding your question about the fourth scale degree, there is a term for such tones. We call them tendency tones, in which they are less stable notes that have the tendency to resolve into more stable notes. A leading tone specifically refers to the 7th degree of the scale. A leading tone is a tendency tone which is the most unstable and tends to lead us to the tonic. Similarly with the fourth too, which tends to lead us to the third. Other tendency notes are the 6th, 2nd, 3rd and 5th, but they have a lesser degree of tendency of resolving. I think this is a good website for reference:  http://www2.siba.fi/muste1/index.php?id=63&la=en Hope I've helped to answer your questions.

But with I-iii-IV, you've repurposed the B into a chord tone. The iii usually goes up to the IV as the IV  Also common is where we have the mediant chord going into the submediant chord. Consider the progression, I-vi-ii-V-I. We can insert the iii before vi to give us I-iii-vi-ii-V-i. Notice also how this is a 'shortened version' of the Circle of Fifths progression without the the IV-viio after I.  In the minor key, the mediant chord is usually first prepared by its secondary subdominant. For example, in the key of C minor, the III, Eb major chord, is usually preceded by Bb major chord, the V of III. Hence we have a chord progression such as i-V/III-III-iv-V-i. The V/III can be inverted as V6/III to give us an ascending bass line. Regarding your question about the fourth scale degree, there is a term for such tones. We call them tendency tones, in which they are less stable notes that have the tendency to resolve into more stable notes. A leading tone specifically refers to the 7th degree of the scale. A leading tone is a tendency tone which is the most unstable and tends to lead us to the tonic. Similarly with the fourth too, which tends to lead us to the third. Other tendency notes are the 6th, 2nd, 3rd and 5th, but they have a lesser degree of tendency of resolving.
